Dapper Broadcom Driver page.

This is a work around for those that claim to have really really followed the all the steps to installing the broadcom driver and can see networks when they run
<pre>
iwlist scan
</pre>

Here's a quick script I wrote that works to get me connected.
<pre>
if [ -z "$2" ]<nowiki>[[BR]]</nowiki>
then<nowiki>[[BR]]</nowiki>
       iwlist  scan | grep ESSID<nowiki>[[BR]]</nowiki>
  echo "+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++  "<nowiki>[[BR]]</nowiki>
  echo "Usage: getit [interface] [essid]  "<nowiki>[[BR]]</nowiki>
  echo "Pick one of the above essid's "<nowiki>[[BR]]</nowiki>
  echo "use the interface that had the essids"<nowiki>[[BR]]</nowiki>
  echo "+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++  "<nowiki>[[BR]]</nowiki>
  exit $E_NOARGS<nowiki>[[BR]]</nowiki>
fi  <nowiki>[[BR]]</nowiki>
echo "Bringing network down"<nowiki>[[BR]]</nowiki>
ifdown eth1 &>3<nowiki>[[BR]]</nowiki>
echo "Bringing network back up"<nowiki>[[BR]]</nowiki>
ifup $1 &>3<nowiki>[[BR]]</nowiki>
echo "Changing to $2"<nowiki>[[BR]]</nowiki>
iwconfig $1 essid $2 &>3<nowiki>[[BR]]</nowiki>
echo "Changing to rate to 11M"<nowiki>[[BR]]</nowiki>
iwconfig $1 rate 11M &>3<nowiki>[[BR]]</nowiki>
echo "acquiring IP"<nowiki>[[BR]]</nowiki>
dhclient $1 <nowiki>[[BR]]</nowiki>
</pre>

The forum link (applies to Dapper, to be released around 4/2006) where this is discussed is http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=114922
